author: Jojumy

title: Rotating platform with actuator (e.g. for timelapse photography)

description.text:
A platform (5cm radius) and a fitting 3-arm-actuator which is connected to a stepper motor with a 5mm coupler and runs on a base made of foamboard. The platform has 3 holes to fix small bearings for smoother moving. Controlled with an Arduino, a stepper motor board and a gear stepper motor with 2048 steps per round. For rotating timelapse videos like this:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4jKaOVkcicg

author: CharlieDancey

title: Electronic module chassis for Raspberry based robots

description.text: I looked for a flexible concept for adding and removing electronic modules during development of a RaspBerry (1) based robot. I finally decided to use my 3D printer for creating a chassis allowing to mount multiple modules on different positions. The square shaped mounting holes are designed for plastic screws (e.g. Sicaplas). I added two model files for the chassis bridge where one of them has a removable bottom plate for better contact to the printing bed.

author: RolandSautner

description.text:
After having massiv problems with my FabTotum - I slowly get really frustrated. One thing what I disliked while fixing once more my printer head (watch out you loose your warranty when you open it!!!) was the flimsy bowden push tube. It is annoying that a dedicated 3D printer company delivers its printer with material from a reused coke bottle. Watch out for the existing O-Ring, that can give you big trouble!

Anyhow, excuse the printing on the top but it became a running gag within the circles of my friends and family.

(As you can see, even with that tube I had printing problems ...)

title: Filter support for pad coffee machine

description.text:
I have a pad coffee machine with two alternative pad holders and a milk hose for Cappuccino. I looked for a tidy way for storing these components while not used. Therefore I designed my own filter support with an integrated milk hose 'tower'.
In addition to the 3D printed parts (I used dark brown PLA) you will need an aluminum pipe and turn off the ends until fitting into the printed base and clamp parts.

author: Lennson

description.text: Power switch for Printrbot Simple Metal. Clips directly to base in front of printer. I wanted a power switch for this printer since I hated plugging and unplugging the power supply every time, especially since it's located under the bed.

Open in Cura and rotate 180 degrees so that it lays flat and tabs are facing up. Infill shouldn't really matter but I went with 20%. The opening is a bit tight and will take some pressing to get the switch in there, but once it's in, it's in.

You'll need electrical tape or wire taps ( your choice), wire cutters/strippers, and some 22-18 gauge wire.

After printing, make all wire connections through the opening and then push switch through. I had pushed the switch in place first which made the wiring harder than it needed to be. After that, run the wires down the channel I cut out in the back and under the base.

Clip the switch holder underneath the base first and bring the top up into place.

The switch I used was a Sure Bilt SB85915 from Autozone.

I'll include a diagram for wiring installation in a day or so.. just have to sketch it out.

title: tomato and strawberry picker with pixy and arduino and stepper

description.text:
upgrade my remote controlled tomato picker
https://www.youtube.com/user/rectsys/videos
with the addition of a pixy camera. now the machine can do the work on its own without remotely controlled by a human. the original telescopic arm/picker is not yet transferred to the new mount yet, but it will be driven by the stepper on the top of the mount. will design and print new arm/picker soon. it will be telescopic too, or something that will fold and extend out with the picker on the far end. the picker(the mechanical hand that will hold and picker the fruit) will be passive, that is, with touch sensor control, the stepper will not calculate the distance.
3 mena 41mm stepper are used on the pixy mount, and 76mm steppers on the frame to move the pixy mount.
the mount uses plastic BB balls between x and y.
grippers modified from files by other thingyverse users.
testing:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL-8tQo-m0qsfoEZP3951SIRg_sDtKz5TE
glue some parts together. the y needs to be modified (cut a corner), so the y part will fit the x part. no time to change the design and print a correct one.

author: alisonleanne

title: Mandalorian Knee Armor - Rav Bralor from Star Wars

description.text:
These are parts to make mandalorian knee armor on a Mandalorian bounty hunter costume from star wars. They are multi segment intentionally so that the middle section can be printed flat and have print lines perpendicular to the side sections.
This will mean you need to print this part with supports. but it will also mean it will be far stronger and one should be able to kneel on this armor without it breaking if you print in ABS. (I recommend you print in ABS or something with some flexibility)
If printed in abs, simply dowsing the middle section in acetone will enable a strong weld with outer sections, I find this is far stronger than using glue. If you do want to use a glue, use plastic cement.

I dont recommend printing this in PLA if you want to be able to kneel directly on this part in your costume.

comments.text:
You are correct.
To be honest the concern in designing this
was not anatomical accuracy, rather a more stylized
look with the intent to make it printable without support.
I do agree that the models could be more accurate but I am often more concerned with the limitations
of FFF(aka FDM) printing (with support being something I strive to avoid).
(and I have a large number that are not accurate)
It is often a bit of an annoyance especially trying to avoid overhangs
when designing, as I end up making weak chins on busts, hats that are angled up at the brim. and so forth.
In the case of the fly, I made the legs WAY fatter and shorter than they ought to be to ensure they print without crumbling before attaching to the body
(a problem i had with a few spider models).
to make an accurate fly, i would make it in pieces and glue it together.
I do appreciate the feedback. I realize the intent is good.
-perry (aka cerberus333)

A couple of months ago I purchased a Sandisk Cruzer Slice USB drive. It originally had a slide-in-slide-out function, however fairly quickly the locking mechanism failed and you had to hold the little release handle tight to stop it closing when plugging it into a USB slot - something that got old very quickly. 
So I thought it was time to give it a new case :) Laser cut from 3mm acrylic - clear top and bottom with a red core & flame.

Laser cut the first two pieces in clear 3mm acrylic (these are the top and bottom) Then cut the 3rd piece in red 3mm acrylic (this is the center slice)
Crack open your USB stick and assemble the 3 pieces together (take care with static sensitive electronics!)
Use water-thin acrylic glue to stick it all together :)

The dogbones of the Losi Micro-T RC models are quite small in size and although they are pretty durable you might still end up breaking them due to wear off... especially if you upgrade your Micro-T with a more powerful battery or a brushless combo. So we've made a 3D printable dogbone that you can print and try on your small scale Losi RC model, these were originally designed to be printed with PLA, but regular PLA is not strong enough (though it may work on stock Micro-T), but printing from ABS does provide a more durable solution that should handle some upgrades. Do note that printing the dogbones with ABS filament may still not be enough if your Micro-T is equipped with brushless motor.

We recommend to print using a finer layer height, 0.1 mm should be just fine as the dogbones are quite small in size and it could be challenging to have them printed properly even at finer resolution. Also make sure that you use support material when printing these, experiment with the position of the dogbone to see which one will result in best quality print on your 3D printer.

This is a replacement bull gear for the Littermaid automatic cat litter box. I designed it for my Littermaid Mega, but it should fit all of the Littermaid models.

This is the main gear that attaches to the motor inside the gray rake arm. If your Littermaid broke and you hear a loud intermittent popping noise followed by the rake getting stuck, you most likely need a new bull gear.

comments.text: Hi Cat Lovers,
comments.author: VelvetLetter

comments.text: Thank you so much, Stix!   I finally had time to get my printed part on the Littermaid, and it is working great!  I wasn't sure about my print job, but it seems to be doing well.  Thanks to you!  I was very surprised to find this on here, and I am definitely not sure how to 'draw up' a gear, so it was so good to find one that you had designed.   I downloaded it, changed some settings on my printer and printed away; all is good now.
comments.author: msgoodwrench

comments.text: hey!  thanks for the reply!   I went ahead and made this cause I wasn't sure if I would get a response since it was an older posting.  My gear that is broken is the one that meshes with the motor (driving) gear, so this should be right.  I thought maybe it was since it showed the screw or pin hole that secures it to the shaft.  I just haven't had time to try and fit it yet.  My quality is not the best either as far as how 'sharp' the teeth are, and if it breaks it would be because of undue stress on the meshing teeth probably.  But, it seemed like a good project for my Printrbot and for me! Did you need to 'prefit' the gear or shave it at all to fit well or 'run it in'? I had fashioned a rudimentary 'strain relief' for the cord at the motor for my older units and made several of them.  My biggest problem there is finding wire that will withstand the constant bending and stresses.  I am using wire for servo motors now, but the stranding isn't the best for this purpose and it needs to be replaced from time to time.  Thank you again for your reply and information.
comments.author: msgoodwrench

comments.text: the part I had made, fit right in no modifications. just the quality was not good so thinking durability may be an issue. good luck with yours. you may try old dot matrix printer cables those went back and forth quite a bit. or flat flex cable.
comments.author: msgoodwrench

comments.text: great!  thanks for the reply and the ideas!  I will have to see what happens with my gear, all in life's lessons!
comments.author: ricardomolina

comments.text: I had one made at makexyz for $9.90 quality was so so, but I installed and got my cleaner working again. hopefully it will last because of the quality of the 3D print was not very good. Thanks to STIX for making the model on this. Took me about 30 minutes to disassemble, install and re-assemble.
comments.author: ricardomolina

comments.text: I have a LitterMaid and was interested in printing this, but you say it fits on the motor shaft?  I have a tooth missing on the driven shaft that fits in the motor housing.  Is this the driving one (ON the motor) or the driven one (on the shaft that extends to both ends of the motor housing?
comments.author: msgoodwrench

comments.text: this was for the one the is driven by the motor. So motor has one (this is not it) and drives this gear. I didn't pay attention but look at the inside one to see if it matches the 2 that ride on the actual unit track.

author: DanielSzus

title: City of Art and Science Garden Accessory

description.text:
This design is inspired by a module of the City of Arts and Science complex in Valencia, Spain. This place in particular is called Umbracle and was design to be a place with fresh air in the hot summer days. The structure is supposed to support the vegetation that would help to make shadow for those visiting this place.
The structure I made could be used as a garden accessory, as a support for the plants.
It can be sized up or down according to your needs and each module can be easily glued up with other or others, side by side or facing each other.
This place made me dream about seeing it one day (as I am not original from Spain) and fortunately I live now just 5 km away from it.
Size up or down and join modules side by side or facing each other. Make as many as you want and join them toghether. I printed it with ABS with no support (0.25 layer hight).

Magnetic stirplate based on a 120mm fan

Materials list:
(1)120x25mm standard computer fan
(2) rare earth magnets, 12.7 mm diameter 3.1mm thick, with 6.3mm hole
(1) stirbar
(1) 500 mL or larger erlenmeyer flask or beaker
(1) power supply 12vdc

How to build:
Wire up fan to 12 vdc supply, make sure it is clean and working.

Check the diameter of the case fan hub to be sure it fits in the spinner.
the magnets should be press-fit into the spinner, and then the spinner can be glued to the fan. I used silicone glue. Turn on fan, and make sure spinner is centered well

Put fan in case, andyou have a stirplate.

Use: put flask on top of plate before turning on power, otherwise the magnets will spin too fast and the stirbar can't keep up.

description.text: We have one of these self-cleaning "robot" cat litter boxes for our 2 cats.  It does a wonderful job of taking care of things, but it is tricky to fill with fresh litter.  You press a button on the machine, it rotates and gives access to fill via a small 8cm x 8cm opening.  Pouring the litter through this awkwardly small hole takes much concentration.  I designed a funnel that fits into this opening to make filling it much easier.
This takes up pretty much my entire PCB heat bed at 170mm x 170mm.  I did 0.3mm layer height with 100% fill, took about 3 hours to print.

comments.text: Thanks!! I love my litter bot but filling it through that hole was hopeless.

center = 20

This is a follow-on to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:904 It is a cylinder with a helical channel. The channel is designed so that the part can be printed without any internal support material. This was printed on a Dimension uPrint with zero internal support material. The hollow channel can then be filled with low-melting-temperature metal alloy to form an electromagnet. Due to the low number of turns, the performance of the electromagnet is poor. This is really just a proof-of-principle of the fabrication method, not much of a practical electromagnet. Malone and Lipson report better results using similar materials with a layer-by-layer approach in the paper "Multi-material Freeform Fabrication of Active Systems" which can be found here: http://creativemachines.cornell.edu/publications The SpoolHead is another promising approach for making embedded conductors. Info here: http://reprap.org/wiki/SpoolHead UPDATE June 27 2011 - Also be sure to check out Rhys Jones' new results on the RepRap page here: http://blog.reprap.org/2011/06/new-approach-to-printing-metals.html

After the part is printed, it can be heated in a water bath and filled with molten alloy using a plastic syringe (see pictures). The process is described in more detail over at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:904 Be careful if you actually try to do anything with low-melt alloy. It is messy, toxic, and hot enough to cause burns. Use it only if you are experienced working in a lab environment. STLs and Alibre source files are provided.

description.text:
A Novelty Desktop Toy. A basic single planetary gear with a piston attached. The ratio is 1:2 allowing for a point on the gear tooth to travel the length of the shell diameter in a linear motion. I've connected a shaft piston to this point using a cut length of paper clip. It probably could be redesigned better. But works fine at the moment :) Enjoy I gave my Printed version away, and didn't take any pics. Ill post some next time I print it again. 5/06/2013
Vertices fixed !
Also Shortened the crankshaft so that it does not protrude as much.
Updated files Files housing.stl and PlanetaryGearAndPiston-ALL-Parts.stl

At the moment there's nothing to connect the end of the con-rod to the gear. I melted a bent piece of Paper clip to the end so that it protruded  down into the hole in the gear tooth (after It was assembled!) and it worked very well but its not ideal.  
I also replaced the 5mm printed shaft between the piston and con-rod with 2x course counter sunk Computer case screws.

comments.text: Brilliant.  I never thought of using a Tusi Couple hypocycloid to easily turn circular motion into linear motion and vise versa.  I always thought Tusi Couples along with epicycloids and hypocycloids were just fancy forms of geometrical art.  I never thought of applying them to something useful.

title: Case for original Raspberry Pi model B

description.text:
Yet another case for the original Raspberry Pi model A and model B. There are a number of these out there already, but none seemed to fit my purpose, so here we go. The two models are the same, except that the top cover for model A has no hole for an ethernet connector. This design is made in OpenSCAD, so should be easy to modify as you see fit.

There are flags so you can optionally have a support shelf for the SD card, an opening for a camera module, openings for the LEDs and external access to the IO pins.

The case is made to snap together, but if you prefer, two countersunk screws can also be added. There is internal structure in the bottom, so you only have to remove a thin layer of plastic to expose the screw holes.

For a similar case for the model B+ and 2 model B, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:978990
Should be a straight forward print in PLA or other material, with for instance 20% infill. If you have issues with warping, a brim support is recommended.

comments.text: Great design. Exactly what I was looking for. Thank you for sharing.

author: egil

description.text:
A project box for a raspberry pi and a few other items. I made it for a cloud server consisting of a Raspberry Pi 2, a 3.5" USB hard disk, and a lithium battery with a recharge circuit.

The box has a vertical opening at one end to keep cable access tidy. The lid has slots and the main box has holes along one side to allow for ventilation etc.
The main box is 63 mm high on the outside.

1. Print the box
  2. Print the lid (a different colour)
  3. Put in your electronics / raspberry pi
  4. Assemble!

title: Direct Drive Chimera/Cyclops Extruder for Prusa i3 - Flexible filament ready

description.text:
Update 5-7: Lever arms updated
Update 12-18:
Changed lever arm so 2 should fit side by side without needed to be sanded down. (untested)
Added flipped lever arm
Added SKP file

Edited my favorite extruder (by the all powerful misan) To mount a E3D Chimera to my I3. Flexible filament ready!

Required hardware:
Grooved bearing
http://folgertech.com/products/623-v-grooved-bearing
Designed for this drive gear (may work with others)
http://folgertech.com/products/steel-feeding-drive-gear-5mm-bore-3d-printer-reprap-prusa-mendel-maker-bot
4mm bowden tubing
various length 3mm machine screws
Extruder springs (I sourced mine from cheap soap dispensers)
Zip ties for wires

Print in ABS or PETG filament with as much infill as required to make sure it won't bend. PLA will probably melt.

Use support for the area near the bearing holes from misans design. I apologize for this, last minute adjustment. Forgot to account for the set screw on the drive gear.

Use spring plug if your tension isn't high enough.

Tight tolerances may require drilling or sanding to get everything snug and spinning freely.

comments.text: Is this compatible with dual e3d titan extruders, nema 17 motors, and the prusa i3, or any of the knock off i3's? Also, what type of mounting hardware does this require, screws, locknuts, washers, etc? Also, would it be difficult for me to add a fan pointed at the bed?
comments.author: mikelee69

comments.text: The E3D titan is an extruder like this is, they do the same job. The titan would replace this setup. This is also not compatible with E3D V6 or any other full size hot end. It is designed specifically for the E3D Cyclops and Chimera. It is compatible with any i3 design that has mounting holes for 2 extruders.

Holder for original M3D filament bobbins. Consists of two parts that can be pressed together and secured with glue or a screw. Placement of the spool is similar to ilikesanta's design; it takes some space, but the filament path is optimized for lowest friction and avoids collisions with any moving parts.

Printed with my M3D using clear PLA on blue tape, medium quality and high fill (5mm cross hatch). Raft and support material turned off. To fit bobby1 turn it 20 deg around Z-axis. Print time is 7h for bobby1 and 3h for bobby2.

comments.text: Two parts to avoid overhangs for better print quality without support material.

title: Sci-fi Chemical Plant - Chemical Processing Tank

description.text:
Sci-fi chemical plant processing tank for tabletop wargames. This model is a preview of a full model pack of the Colmar chemical plant (Pyre Light). Visual design inspired by MechWarrior 2 building models. Originally designed for 6mm BattleTech (1/285), using 1 hex = 1.75" (1.5in with .125" gutter, similar to HeroScape terrain). Can be scaled to fit other game scales.

If working in mm in your slicing software, scale the .STL by 25.4.

Feedback welcome - please comment!

Multiply scale by 25.4 if working in mm.

Designed for single-extruder .5mm ABS filament. Object is manifold with minimized undercuts and should print successfully with any thermoplastic filament extrusion, powder substrate (3DSystems / zCorp), or similar additive process.

Hex base may not be needed for this model, but if desired will need to be acquired separately.

Not suitable for small children.

author: Curtisbeef

title: Straw holder for PC duster / WD40

description.text:
Hello everyone,

This is a simple straw holder that I made for a can of PC duster. After a while I always lose the straw which made me consider this. This is my first thing and computer aided design. As a programmer I loved using OpenSCAD.

Update: After playing with OpenSCAD I updated the files and exported separate STL's for both cans. The PC duster version is 57.75mm and the WD40 version is 65.85mm.

If you need to modify the diameter of the ring of straw you can edit the SCAD file by simply changing the variables at the top.

If you want to know exactly how I sliced the STL file you can download and open the included factory file in Simplify3d 3.0.

Material: ColorFabb PLA/PHA
Temp: 210c
Extrusion height: 0.2mm
Infill: 35%
Speed: 40mm/s

If you like this give me a shout since it is my first thing 8^)

I came across a snag with my external camera flash when designing the Rotobooth (my flickr photobooth).  The flash, a Canon 430ex, does not have a DC power option (the ability to plug into an external power source).  This would require the four AA batteries to be swapped out approximately every 200 photos.  
My boombox takes 6 X D batteries, so it was an incentive to design for the next size battery.

I have not used high current on these batteries yet, so you may need a regulator before running the leads (don't melt it into you battery compartment)! Thanks Corey.
Also, I used screws on either side of the batteries to affix the leads and glued some copper mesh to maximize surface area of the conductors.
The cross braces aren't straight since i made em with the pencil tool, but they still work structurally.  It's still a slow print, so I'll probably make a lesser diameter on the inside cylinder.

description.text:
Do you like butterfly knives? Then make your own butterfly knife key holder! Perfect for practising tricks or opening your locks in style.

What you need to print:

  • 2 key holders (handles)
  • 1 key bit (part that attaches to your key)

Assembly:
Use some M3 bolts and nuts to secure everything in place. The key can be taped to the key bit. I originally planned to use a screw to hold the key in place but I found tape to be more convenient.

Printed in PLA at 10% infill
No supports required
Extruder temp: 210
Bed temp: 60

Just print two of these and zip-tie around base and loom.

author: schooldrafting

title: Clipon 40mm fan mount for Kossel Mini 2020

description.text:
This fan mount just clips on the inside of the lower frame of a 2020 aluminium Kossel Mini (in my case a Folger Tech kit). I use three of these clips to have some air movement over the tower stepper motors in order to keep them cool.

Each fan is mounted on the rail about 0.5-1 inch away from the stepper motor and blowing over the side and rear. This keeps the stepper motors nice and cool, whereas before I would have failed prints due to overheating motors.

To me this is an essential upgrade for any (FolgerTech) kossel!
Mount fan with 12mm M3 bolts and nuts.

comments.text: Are these to be mounted horizontally or vertically ?
comments.author: cjalas

comments.text: The clips are supposed to go in the top and bottom 2020 rails of the base assembly, so the fan blows horizontally on the motors (pay attention to the airflow direction).
comments.author: cjalas

description.text:
Watch the video: https://youtu.be/IAqOGs5mrKg

This Gatling-gun style card shooter will liven up your bridge game - just turn the crank and deal your next hand at 30 MPH! The crank is connected to an eccentric feed wheel that feeds one card per revolution. The drive wheel at the business end is geared up by 25:1 to reach speeds of more than 3000 RPM. Pulling the trigger drops the deck onto the feed wheel, and then watch the cards fly!

This thing is designed so it will fit on a 150mm x 150mm print bed.

CAUTION: Do not shoot at humans, animals or siblings - you could put an eye out.

UPDATE: You can now buy all the non-printed parts for this thing from:
https://www.freewebstore.org/assemble-store
(note: I am not affiliated with assemble.network)

Update: I've revised the crank and eccentric parts to make them stronger. The new versions use a screw going through the entire assembly to keep the crank from breaking. Note the revised assembly instructions.

Update: I've added a "topcard" piece which is a weighted card loaded with pennies to add some downward force on the feed wheel. This greatly improves the feeding reliability.

You'll need the following 3D printed parts:
leftside.stl
rightside.stl
drivewheel.stl
clustergear.stl
eccentric.stl
trigger.stl
tray.stl
stop.stl
crank.stl
knob.stl
topcard.stl

plus:
7 - 608ZZ bearings
2 - 330 Dash no. O-rings
13 - 4-40 x 1/4" screws
1 - 4-40 x 1" panhead screw
1 - 4-40 nut
1 - #4 washer
1 - Standard poker-sized deck of cards (textured finish cards work best)

All parts were printed in PLA with 0.2mm layer thickness, 3 perimeters and 20% infill. Use a perimeter line width of 0.4mm for optimal printing. The drive wheel, the cluster gear, the eccentric wheel, the trigger, the crank and the tray all require supports, but they should break away easily. The right side, left side, knob and stop parts print without supports. If your printer does not have a heated bed, print the parts with a raft to make sure they come out flat.

Assembly:

  1. Put one O-ring in the groove of the drive wheel and the other O-ring in the groove of the eccentric wheel.
    (UPDATE: Press the 4-40 nut into the hexagonal depression in the back of the eccentric wheel. Use some superglue if it won't stay put..)
  2. Inserting bearings in bottom sides of the eccentric wheel, the cluster gear and the drive wheel.
  3. On the left side, break the end leaf spring loose and flex it back & forth to make sure it is detached from the body of the part.
  4. Hold the leaf spring flexed back while inserting the trigger over the 3 screw bosses. Screw the trigger down with 3 of the screws. Make sure the trigger and leaf spring operate smoothly.
  5. Place the eccentric hub and bearing on the post at the "muzzle" end of the shooter. Place the cluster gear and bearing on the middle post. Place the eccentric wheel and bearing on the post towards the handle.
  6. Put bearings on the post ends of the eccentric wheel, cluster gear and drive wheel.
  7. Place the right side on top of the assembly, sliding the bearings into the matching cavities. Screw the two sides together. There are three screw holes on the right side face, and one screw hole at the front end of the shooter.
  8. Slide the stop piece into the tray with the finger pointing down and flat side of the finger facing the inside of the tray. Secure with a screw and washer. Make sure the end of the screw does not stick into the tray cavity.
  9. Flex the ears on the end of the tray apart slightly and slide in the last bearing.
  10. Attach the tray to the body with 4 screws. The back end of the tray should be resting against the body. Adjust the height of the front of the tray so that the bearing is just barely touching the O-ring on the drive wheel. (Too much contact pressure will make the crank very hard to turn.)
  11. Slide the knob onto the end of the crank and secure with a screw. Make sure the knob spins freely. Slide the crank onto the end of the shaft sticking out from the eccentric wheel and secure with the 1" long 4-40 screw. This long screw should thread into the nut you inserted into the eccentric in Step 1.
  12. Place the deck of cards in the tray. With the trigger pulled, adjust the stop up or down so that just one card can slip under the tip of the stop. Place the topcard piece (with each pocket loaded with 5 pennies) on top of the deck.

Operation:
The trigger piece has a nub on the end which pushes the deck up away from the eccentric feed wheel. When the trigger is pulled, the deck drops down in contact with the eccentric. Turning the crank
rotates the eccentric O-ring, which rises up from the body as it rotates forward. If the trigger is pulled, the bottom card will be pushed forward until it is pinched between the high-speed drive wheel and the bearing, and then launched out the front. The drive wheel is off-center, and there is also a slot in the side of the tray, so that as the card is driven forward, it also rotates. This rotation is what makes the card cut through the air like a frisbee rather than just fluttering aimlessly.

Tips:
If your bearings are lubricated with grease instead of oil, wash out the grease with WD-40. At high speeds, the grease will give you too much rolling resistance.

If you happen to have bearings with rubber seals instead of sheilds (like me) remove the rubber seals to reduce the rolling resistance.

Lubricate the gears with a little light grease or Vaseline.

Do not turn the crank more than 2-3 rev/second - trying to go faster will either break the crank shaft of melt the PLA gears.

Have fun, be safe.

comments.author: dragon_2012

comments.text: The photo of the partially assembled gear train shows best what is going on.  The first gear (towards the handle) has a big gear barely visible underneath the rubber tire that drives the small gear of the middle gear cluster with about a 5:1 step-up ratio.  The big gear on the middle cluster then drives the small gear on the output wheel with another 5:1 step-up ratio, so overall, the output wheel is going 25x faster than the input crank.  Also, note that the rubber tire on the input crank is slightly eccentric so that once per revolution of the crank, it rises up and pushes the bottom playing card forward into the output wheel, which then grabs it and launches the card at high speed.
comments.author: dragon_2012

author: Digitalchocolate

description.text: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Garden http://www.theonion.com/

The fan cooling my stepper drivers was causing a draft near the hot end, so I designed this simple air deflector that screws directly to your fan. It is configurable so you can customize it to fit any fan.

Not soft unless you print it with a flexi filament, but at least they're round and unlike the ones we bought that tape on these can't be pulled off by the rugrat. Two screws from the bottom side that don't go all the way through so no scars after they're removed.

Printed upright as in the STL, with a single hot end using Slic3r and forcing support for the first 30 layers to create something like a glorified raft. 5%-10% 3D infill is more than enough, the ball shape gives a lot of natural strength. I even did the walls at only 2 layers. My printer is a Makerfarm i3v 12".

This was made to attach to our 20mm thick coffee table top (see pics). You'll probably want to remix this for your specific table top thickness. Easiest way to do that is to edit it on Tinkercad and "ungroup" it until you find the square hole. Resize the square hole and put it back together.

author: PinballGeorgio

description.text:
This is the Lancelot mech from the anime Code Geass. It took about a week to finish, that included test prints and assembly to see if the parts fit together properly, and printing, painting and assembly of the final model. All the models were made on 123D Design. Some of the details had to be changed for the inclusion of ball and socket joints so the whole thing can articulate as well as making it easier to print out.
A few of the parts need to be printed twice because they are symmetrical: Shoulder, Landspinners, Thigh, Hand, Thigh plate, Sword, Scabbard, Bracer.
The parts were put together with superglue ,and all the ball and sockets just snap together, the joint that attach the feet to the legs are bit difficult to snap in, and the socket in the shoulder should be assembled around its ball. One thing I noted while putting it together was that the joints got easier to move over time and became loose, to fix that I lined the inside of the sockets with thin strips of craft foam. For the fingers, sword guards, rifle and wheels I used small pieces of 22 gauge wire to allow them to pivot. I printed it out in PLA with 10% fill on a printrbot simple.

My desktop is always a mess, full of cables everywhere. I created this little cable holder hive. It is meant to be used with small cables, but you can always scale it. Enjoy.

UPDATE:

Since this item is far more popular than I expected I decided to upload 2 new versions for larger cables.

UPDATE 2 (26/10/2017)

Model has been modified so that the hive has the same wall thickness everywhere.

Small size is now 120mm tall
Medium size is now 140mm tall
Large size is now 180mm tall

I believe medium size is the best choice.

Since this is a very simple design, these settings are more than enough:

Infill: 0.4
Layer height: 0.3
Support : NO
Bottom solid layers: 3

title: DJI Phantom 3 & Inspire 1 Range Extender – Version D

description.text:
This easy-to-print Range Extender will extend the range of your Phantom 3 or Inspire 1 substantially. It slips onto the standard un-modified DJI Controller Antennas and can be quickly installed or removed with one hand – even when your quadcopter is airborne.

Note: This Version "D" has a fairly wide ‘focus’ which make it easy to use, but results in a slightly lower overall 'gain' than my Version "E" model (Thingiverse #962316). They are so easy to print successfully and assemble that you may want to try both of them.

The Range Extender was created using accurate parabolic curves, and with the antenna mounts centered at the parabolic focal points to maximize signal gain and overall effectiveness.

The only consideration for using this parabolic reflector effectively (and any other high-gain antenna, for that matter) is that you ensure your antenna is directly facing the quadcopter. Thanks to DJI, that is very simple, even when your quadcopter may be out of your direct sight. Simply note the position of the green line that appears on your DJI Pilot or DJI GO application map that runs between where you are standing and where the quadcopter is currently located on the map, and turn your controller to face directly up that green line towards the quadcopter. That strategy will ensure maximum antenna gain and the longest possible communications range.

I’ve tested this DJI Phantom 3 / Inspire 1 Range Extender with my Phantom 3 Pro, and it works very well, delivering substantially more maximum effective range. Please note that no antenna range extender works well through heavy cover (such as through dense forests) or from behind large solid objects (such as behind hills or large buildings). Best performance will always be obtained with a line-of-sight signal path between the controller and quadcopter – even when the quadcopter is beyond your visual range. If you pay close attention to the Remote Controller Signal Strength Indicator and the HD Video Link Signal Strength Indicator, you’ll know exactly how strong your signal is, and when you are reaching the limits of your range.

All parts print without support, and require very little post-print finishing. Both the Parabolic Reflector Shell and the Antenna Mounts have been designed as thin and lightweight as possible, while still ensuring adequate strength and durability. Total Finished Weight= 49.2grams.

Please share your Makes and any suggestions you have for improvements.

Print all the parts: 1 Parabolic Base, and 2 each of the Top and Bottom Mounts. I used the following settings on my MakerBot Replicator 5th Generation: PLA; Standard Profile; Infill=25%; Layer Height=0.20mm; Infill Layer Height=0.20mm; Shells=3; Raft=Yes; Supports=No. Print times were approximately: 6.5 hours for the Parabolic Base and 1 hour for the Set of 4 Antenna Mounts

Additional parts required for assembling the Range Extender (which I purchased at Home Depot):
• 4 each #4x1/2” Pan Head Sheet Metal Screws (~$1.18 / 8)
• 1 each Reflectix Multi-Purpose FOIL TAPE FT210 – 2” x 30’
Note: Another Thingiverse contributor found 4” wide foil tape on Amazon which would be a perfect size for this project. You may want to consider that alternative although I thought I might have trouble working with such large pieces.

Assembly:
First, cut two pieces of the Foil Tape, each slightly longer than necessary to cover the full width of the Parabolic Base (about 25cm each). Remove a little over half the backing on the first piece. Then, center the first piece near the top of the Base (about 1mm from the top edge); ensure that both ends of the foil are ‘square’ with the top edge of the Base. Then, working from the center towards one outside edge, slowly stick down and smooth the first foil piece down and across to the outside edge. Make sure the foil wraps slightly around the outside edge and leave the excess for now. Try to avoid creases or ‘bubbles’ as you install the foil.

Second, remove the backing from the other side of the first foil piece, and smooth it down over the second side, again taking care to keep it aligned about 1mm down from the top edge of the Base. Again, make sure the foil wraps slightly around the outside edge and leave the excess for now.

Third, follow the same general steps for the bottom half of the Parabolic Base. Try hard to have the top and bottom foils meet as close as possible, but not overlap.

Forth, take some time to smooth the foil across the complete Parabolic Base, removing any bubbles or wrinkles, and sharpening the center spine as much as possible. The smoother the foil is, the better the reflector will perform.

Fifth, take a razor blade or very sharp knife and cut off the excess foil along both outside edges, leaving just enough to smooth around the outside edges with your fingernail.

Now, ‘punch’ out each hole from the front (foil) side of the Parabolic Base. You may also want to enlarge each of the 4 Parabolic Reflector holes slightly (to around 3mm) so that the Screws will barely barely slide through the holes smoothly.

Then, set one Bottom Mount on a flat surface, smooth, rounded side up, and push the Parabolic Base up to it on the foil side, right side up; push the first Screw through the back of the Base and into the Bottom Mount, carefully holding the parts together. I held the Mount down with my thumb and pushed it hard against the Base with my knuckle. It may help to turn the Screw forward half a turn, then back a little bit, then forward again, repeating as you go – this will reduce the effort required to install the screws. Assemble the second Bottom Mount in the same manner.

Finally, turn the Parabolic Base upside down and install the 2 Top Mounts (upside down) in the same manner as above. Assembling the Mounts in this manner will ensure that they are aligned correctly. Take a look at the gaps between the Antenna Mounts and the foil tape and further tighten any screws which are not fully seated. Correct vertical alignment of the Antenna Mounts will ensure that the Range Extender will slide on and off the DJI Controller easily.

Test the Range Extender on your DJI Controller, and make any necessary adjustments to the alignment of the Mounts. You may also need to file the inside of each mount slightly to clean up any stray filament or remove rough edges.

Have Fun! Fly Safe!

comments.text: Thanks for an easily printable design that's also easy to install and remove. I especially like the mounting clamps. I printed one of these in PLA (reflector) and PETG (mounts) and then tapped the mounts for 3mm nylon machine screws. The clamps fit the Phantom's antennas very well and the reflector performs as well as can be expected. I did the calculations (I'm an engineer) and this design should provide 5 to 6 dBi of gain at 2.4GHz. Very nice considering you don't have to open up the transmitter to add connectors and then bolt on antennas that causes the transmitter to no longer fit in DJI' s Phantom 4 hard foam case.
comments.author: mlewus

comments.author: Pr0pwash

comments.text: Another maker, from Poland no less, used 4" Copper foil tape and told me he got great results.  Since both aluminum and copper are are highly conductive metals, I can't see why it wouldn't work just fine.  If you try it, please post your results here for others to see.  Thanks!  -mike-  PS: It sure was pretty!
comments.author: Pr0pwash

comments.text: Virtually all metals will function as a RF reflector.  Electrons in metals are free partials and thus will not absorb RF.  Zinc, copper, brass, tin, aluminum.  It doesn't matter.  Pick a cheap and durable metallic tape and run with it.  Won't see any difference in output RF signal.
comments.author: mswarden

comments.text: I did the calculations and at microwave frequencies, any copper or aluminum tape that is thick enough for you to handle will work fine. I used 5 mil (0.125mm) copper tape on mine. Remember, though, our parabolic reflectors don't just focus RF energy on the Phantom's antenna, they also focus light. So you want whatever you use to not be too reflective of light. I suggest you lightly sand it with 600 grit paper to scuff it up if need be, to prevent overheating the plastic antenna sheath at the focal point of the reflector.
comments.author: Wolfie

comments.text: I just made another set (first one was for my P3A).  The first set I used foil tape for ducts (Home Depot).  This set I decided to cut a mountain dew can and use contact cement to adhere it to the printed reflector.  Looks different than the shiny foil tape as the interior of the can is a semi-gloss.  I scuffed up the outside of the can prior to cutting using a green scrub pad.  Cut using a box knife blade in a book on the bench.  I folded the aluminum strip in half to match the center of the double arch and glued it in place using common rubber cement.  Then trimmed the ends using a box knife and smoothed the edges with the back of a spoon.
Made it, love it !!

title: GPS Disc Mount Hobby King Color 250 Quad

description.text: I needed a way to mount my puck disc GPS to my Color 250 Quad fro Hobby King. This is what i came up with.

I printed this in PLA at 50% fill on a raft.
To mount you use the extra aluminum posts you get in the box.
I then cut a long 3mm screw in half to make 2 all threads.
I CA glued them into the aluminum posts.
These then screw into the quad frame as pictured and the new printed plate on top of that with the original screws.
Then just hot glue or double sided tape the GPS to the plate.
Makes a Great Handle to pick the quad up with also.

title: Star Trek Voyager EMH mobile emitter

description.text:
Help with my next creation!
There are a few good representations of the Doctors Mobile emitter on-line but none that were just right so here is mine. It has some circuitry on it to give some detail without needing to get a PCB and cut it to size which all of the ones I have found need.
Video here. Open link in new window to skip straight to the item.
There are 2 versions of the emitter, one without holes on the back and one with.
The holes are meant for these magnets which also go in the triangular part so that you can attach it without pins or velcro. I have also included an adaptor so you can use a baby pin to attach it.
Ive got the mind to make a few more pins/badges from Star Trek which will use the same pin and magnet layout so they are interchangeable so keep an eye out for that :)
Follow me on Twitter, Instagram and YouTube To keep apprised of new designs and my other projects.

description.text:
I saw this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V6T0U9yEw0I a few years ago but didn't really have a use for it but now with 3d printing and using PLA I needed a small sander that wasn't too fast, normal sanders move so fast it just melts the plastic.
Enter the Spin Brush sander I used an old Spin Brush because that is what I had and I have a rounded back and forth sanding surface and a flat square sanding area in one toothbrush, the edges are extended out to get into the tight areas where the head of the brush just can't fit.
I included the Sketchup file in case you need to modify it as the toothbrush I used is almost eight years old, who knows if they have changed since then.
Here is a video of it working https://youtu.be/B9w12FLegwE

I printed it with PLA with Cura 0.4mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer height, 90% infill.
I pulled the bristles out with some needle nose pliers, you need to get a good grip, it was far easier than cutting them off though.
I glued the disks on to the SpinBrush with some super glue.
For the the sandpaper I have some stick on that I cut the shapes out of but a bit of glue stick and holding it on for a minute works well also, with the glue stick it leaves paper when you pull it off but nothing a drop of water won't take care of.

title: Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore

description.text:
The Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore (Cathedral of Saint Mary of the Flower), is the main church of Florence, Italy. Construction began in 1296, and was not completed until 1436 until development of new structural materials in the modern era, the dome was the largest in the world. It remains the largest brick dome ever constructed.

I chose this structure, not only because of the vast beauty, but the complexity, and scale for the time of its construction.

I have considered designing this cathedral in the past, and this challenge gave me the perfect opportunity to do just that!

The above photos acted as references, and guidelines to aid my design of this structure. By no means is my design exact, but feel free to compare!

The purpose its split into two, is obviously to see the interior! If you wish to display the model you can close and/or open the model as you see fit! Who wouldn't want to see both the inside, AND outside of this beautiful structure!

I have been attempting to print the model for the past two days...and due to a damaged part, and a clog issue in my printer, I'm unable to get this print done by the deadline date. I must fix this issue first, and I fear I may need some replacement parts...By some miracle that I can get my printer to finish the model, I will be posting pictures of the 3D printed model itself.

The model was designed completely in Google sketchup Make. It was a fun, long, and often frustrating ride to get this model finished. I am confident in my design, and I stand by it when I say, go ahead and print it! If there are any issues, let me know, I'll be sure to modify the file as needed.

Please share your photos if you print it! I'd love to see others enjoying my work! :)

UPDATE - Combined both STL files into a single structure (internals removed).

Simply adjust the model settings to whichever build volume, and layer height you prefer, and print!

NO support structures needed.

No supports, and I used Cura for Robo3D to slice it. It took me a total of 42 hours: 18 for the smaller side in clear PLA, and 23 for the larger side in wood. I has a lot of stringing, but that was only with the wood. Great design!

description.text:
This kit of 3D objects makes a cable hanger to be hooked to a door without screws. It is suitable for 6 feet cables assuming that the door is 80 inches high. Each cable holder section has 18 teeth or 17 grooves. Each groove is 3 cm deep. One cable holder section is 17.5 cm wide. A two mm clearance is required between the door's top and the door frame.

You will need to print a least one "Door Hook Left.stl", one "Door Hook Right.stl" and one "Cable Holder.stl". You can employ more than one "Cable Holder.stl". For each supplementary "Cable Holder.stl" used, you will need to print one "Door Hook Middle.stl".

On the picture, there is:
1 x "Door Hook Left.stl"
1 x "Door Hook Right.stl"
3 x "Cable Holder.stl"
2 x "Door Hook Middle.stl"

Glue may be required to assemble the Cable Hanger together.

description.text:
SeaTheWorld

The Maunsell naval (sea) forts, built in the Thames estuary and operated by the Royal Navy, were to deter and report German air raids following the Thames as a landmark, and attempts to lay mines by aircraft in this important shipping channel.
(wiki link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maunsell_Forts)

Note

If you all really like this fort, I’d be happy to make a full desk play set (there are a few versions of this building that have radio towers, cannons, look out decks, etc). Let me know :)

Pictures by Neil Brown (thanks!)
(http://www.flickr.com/photos/mrbeama)
Blog post with some amazing pictures
(http://desertedplaces.blogspot.com/2014/01/maunsell-forts-abandoned-sea-forts-from.html)

I designed this to be printed with minimal support. It requires some assembly.

  1. Flip the legs over, the top of the legs fit into the square cutout on the bottom of the structure.
  2. The crane arm fits into the slot directly above the door on the backside.

There is a correct orientation for the legs and the support pegs sticking out from the sides. These pegs will line up flush with the edge of the structure model.

Model was printed using ABS and shrinkage has been taken into account and tested.

Settings: Structure / Legs / Crane
Layer: 0.2
Shells: 3 / 3 / 3
Infill: 10% / 30% / 30%
Raft: On / On / On
Support: Off / On / Off

NOTE: Depending on your printer / luck, you may want to use super glue to fix the guide pegs to the structure in case they warped during printing.

Halo Hunter Model.

===THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS. It will probably not print at the moment. Updates are coming.===

I noticed there weren't any models of the Hunter so I made one. I am in the process of slicing him up next so he can be printed in pieces. He is made for 15mm scale gaming so you will probably need to scale him up for other purposes.

Update 01Apr2017: I have cut the hunter into pieces so that he can be reposed. I am using TinkerCAD for the posing because it makes combining all the pieces via boolean a lot easier. The pieces are not made to be printed separately (yet) so you cannot print the pieces and pose him afterward. I will work on that. Also the posed model does not include spines. Those are very hard to print so it's better if they are on their own and attached later. Quills are still a work in progress for what looks good but is still sturdy enough.

title: Wireless QI charger base Version 3 for Nexus 7 - Modified for existing stand

description.text:
NOTE: This is designed to fit a 2013 Nexus 7 without a case, unlike the previous versions with the poetic revolution case.

Had a co-worker ask me to modify my version of the Nexus 7 wireless qi charger I designed to fit his stand he had for his desk.

This is a modified version of the 2nd version - in black. I peeled back the top / right side of the guard to allow easy access to power and sound buttons. The back of the unit has a 3mm channel for a USB cable to be routed out the bottom left edge when plugged in and standing up in portrait mode.

Here is the stand this was designed to fit: http://www.amazon.com/STOUCH-Stands-Mini-Multi-Adjustable-E-Readers/dp/B00VFFBDZK/ref=sr_1_32?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1438817807&sr=1-32&keywords=tablet+stand

If you've not seem my other versions, here is the link to the QI charger this is designed for: http://www.amazon.com/Wireless-Charging-Plate-Smart-phones/dp/B00HJ2KEMQ/ref=sr_1_14?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1424476030&sr=1-14&keywords=wireless+qi+charger

author: vanhulagen

description.text:
YouTube Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3O-guaq50j8

The U Mansion was inspired by a Mansion I saw in a Bollywood movie. The U Mansion was created using a 3D Object building software called SketchUp. The design started from a single sheet of filament placed virtually on the base of the software as a property location. Then the floorplan for the building was made, and the building was created.    

The building was created by a series of push/ pull and erase. The first step was to pull the floor plan so it is 3d object. Then, the door was centered and creating using the curved line tool. The windows in the front were made using the circle tool and a good amount of circles were created making sure none overlapped. The side windows were next made using the rectangle tool and so were the back and front, side windows. The back door was made also using the rectangle tool. After all the doors and windows were created, the center portion of each door and window was erased. Then, I placed  rectangles on the inside of the right and left side of the building to show floors as they will be able to be seen from the outside of the building. After the interior and exterior sides of the building was done, the last step was to create the top/ roof of the building. According to the movie, the mansion had a rectangular pool on one side the roof with tables on the other side. I created the pool and dive board using rectangles and the push/pull tool. The tables were created using the same circles that were used for the front windows of the building and the push/pull tool. On the top of the building, The  fencing was also made using three rectangles that connected and he push/pull tool. Now the Mansion/ Main Building was completed, I needed to finish the front of the building.    

The movie showed that the Mansion had a one way, half circle drive thru and a fountain. The drive thru was once again made using the half circle tool. I had to use the tool two times in order to make both sides of the drive thru. I then lifted the drive thru a bit to show it was a drive thru and not a part of the lawn of the mansion. The fountain was made partially the same way. First, in the center of the drive thru, and in front of the building I laid down 5 circles, one inside the other. Then, I used the push/pull tool to make them like a tower pulling one circle at a time. Finally I made a sixth circle on top of the fountain and then erased it to show the tube for water to flow from. After this step,  the Mansion was finished.    

Along the way, I had to redesign the the windows a bit because I could not compare all the actual dimension of the building compared to the windows because I did not have an actual blueprint or design of the building in hand. Other than that, the design was made according to the photos and video in the movie. My model can not move as it is an building and does not have any moving parts like a motor or robot. My model is cool because it shows a replica of  something in the world I have not seen by my own eyes but from video and pictures from a  movie I have seen.  

In order to print the model correctly I recommend using both supports and rafts. Also, I recommend printing the model the way is was created and have the building straight. Not on it’s sides or back. Also, don’t forget to make sure the model is laid flat to the printing bed at time of printing. By following these steps, you should have a successful print.

The building was created by a series of push/ pull and erase. The first step was to pull the floor plan so it is 3D object. Then, the door was centered and creating using the curved line tool. The windows in the front were made using the circle tool and a good amount of circles were created making sure none overlapped. The side windows were next made using the rectangle tool and so were the back and front, side windows. The back door was made also using the rectangle tool. After all the doors and windows were created, the center portion of each door and window was erased. Then, I placed  rectangles on the inside of the right and left side of the building to show floors as they will be able to be seen from the outside of the building. After the interior and exterior sides of the building was done, the last step was to create the top/ roof of the building. According to the movie, the mansion had a rectangular pool on one side the roof with tables on the other side. I created the pool and dive board using rectangles and the push/pull tool. The tables were created using the same circles that were used for the  front windows of the building and the push/pull tool. On the top of the building, The fencing was also made using three rectangles that connected and the push/pull tool. Now the Mansion/ Main Building was completed, I needed to finish the front of the building.    

The movie showed that the Mansion had a oneway, half circle drive thru and a fountain. The drive thru was once again made using the half circle tool. I had to use the tool two times in order to make both sides of the drive thru. I then lifted the drive thru a bit to  show it was a drive thru and not a part of the lawn of the mansion. The fountain was made partially the same way. First, in the center of the drive thru, and in front of the building I laid down 5 circles, one inside the other. Then, I used the push/pull tool to  make them like a tower pulling one circle at a time. Finally I made a sixth circle on top of the fountain and then erased it to show the tube for water to flow from. After this step, the Mansion was finished.

I originally made a leveling platform for my Printrbot Simple out of some 1" MDF and some T-Nuts. I attached my Printrbot to the leveling platform which gave me a surface to mount a third post to. I used this situation to make this platform spool holder attached to the two existing 8mm posts and the 3rd post that I installed. I plan to make a bracket for the 8mm rod to attach to the Printrbot base for those who don't use a leveling platform.
I used ABS with full support and raft at 230c.
funnel for filling 1/2 in rocket tubes

Not as cute and cuddly as a companion cube (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:152431), but far more practical. That is, if you happen to have a Glidermatic GTS garage door opener AND you mounted one of the remotes to the wall AND you have managed to break it AND if you have a 3D printer. Does this sound like you? Then we have one thing in common and I hope this helps.

  • Spacing on mounting holes is same original bracket.
  • Step on one side of bracket helps the remote face be flush to wall (as it is not symmetrical).

The one in the picture is made with Black ABS on a Printrbot Simple Metal. Flat back helps ensure a good print. The bracket overlap took a bit of trial and error to make one that holds well but is still easy to snap the control into.

I've included the SketchUp master file for ease of remixing.
